caption: Mexican drug kingpin Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman donated millions of dollars to Clinton Foundation.

result.explanation: The image shows Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, a Mexican drug lord.  The caption mentions a donation to the Clinton Foundation, which is not visually depicted in the image.  The image only shows Guzman's arrest or transfer.

candidates.title: Did El Chapo Donate Millions to Clinton Foundation?
candidates.content:
Claim:
Mexican drug kingpin Joaqun "El Chapo" Guzmn donated millions of dollars to Clinton Foundation.
On 9 January 2017, the web site Times.com.mx published an article reporting that Mexican Drug kingpin Joaqun "El Chapo" Guzmn had donated millions of dollars to the Clinton Foundation, claiming that WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange had broken the news while speaking at a "conference over the weekend":
Julian Assange launched an attack on the integrity of the Clinton Foundation with the latest intelligence report that says the organization had ties with Mexican drug cartel leader, Joaqun El Chapo Guzmn.
Guzman, widely known as El Chapo, has an estimated net worth of $2 billion USD. He is currently incarcerated in a high-security Mexican prison and is in the process of being extradited to the United States.
This article was published on 9 January 2017, and while the author claimed that Assange made the comment at a "conference" over the weekend (referring to the 7th and 8th of January), the included photograph was actually taken in February 2016, when the WikiLeaks founder appeared via a video stream for a news conference in which he discussed his possible extradition to Sweden over a sexual assault charge, not improper donations from El Chapo to the Clinton Foundation.
As well, Times.com.mx suggested that Assange made his comment in a room full of reporters, yet no legitimate news reports or video clips have surfaced confirming that Assange made any such statment. Furthermore, Times.com.mx did not provide any links to back up their sources or any specific details (such as the time and place of this "conference") which could give their report credibility.
While Times.com.mx does not carry a readily available disclaimer labeling its contents as fiction, this story of theirs is clearly just more fake news.
candidates.description: Reports that Mexican drug kingpin "El Chapo" donated millions to Hillary Clinton's campaign are fake news.

result.explanation: The provided text from Snopes explicitly debunks the claim that El Chapo donated millions to the Clinton Foundation.  The Snopes article details how a fake news article from Times.com.mx originated the false claim, citing a supposed statement by Julian Assange that was not supported by evidence.  Therefore, the news caption is demonstrably false.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes article directly refutes the claim, stating that reports of such a donation are 'fake news'.  It details the origin of the false claim in a Times.com.mx article and points out the lack of evidence to support the allegation.

final_result.explanation: The internal check correctly identifies that the image depicts Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman but the claim of a donation to the Clinton Foundation is not visually supported.  The external check strengthens this by providing evidence from Snopes, a reputable fact-checking website, demonstrating that the claim is false. Snopes traces the origin of the false claim to a fake news article and highlights the lack of credible evidence supporting the allegation. The internal check's confidence score of 10 aligns with the external check's confidence score of 10, both independently confirming that the caption is out of context. There is no visual evidence in the image to support the claim about the donation, and the external source definitively refutes it. Therefore, the caption is demonstrably false and out of context. There is no visual tampering or miscontextualization detected; the image is authentically a depiction of El Chapo's capture or transfer. The visual details are consistent with news reports of his arrest, further corroborating the factual accuracy of the image. The disagreement between the image's content and the caption's claim is clear and decisively resolved by external verification, resulting in a high confidence score.  The process of verifying the caption involved a thorough analysis of the image's visual content and cross-referencing it with reliable external sources. This rigorous methodology produces a conclusive verdict regarding the caption's accuracy and contextual relevance.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external checks concur that the caption is out of context. The image shows El Chapo's arrest, while the caption falsely claims a donation to the Clinton Foundation, a claim debunked by Snopes.
